alert.note: Alert for Eastern Black Range Foothills; Sierra County Lakes; Southern Gila Foothills, Mimbres Valley; Southern Gila Highlands, Black Range; Uplands of the Bootheel (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS El Paso (Southern New Mexico and extreme Western Texas)
info.headline: Air Quality Alert issued May 31 at 3:31PM MDT by NWS El Paso
info.description: ...AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 PM MDT WEDNESDAY... The New Mexico Departments of Health and Environment has issued an Air Quality Alert, until 1 PM MDT Wednesday. An Air Quality Alert for Smoke has been issued. * WHAT... Smoke from active or new fires will generally be carried toward the northeast this afternoon; however, lighter transport winds will result in less smoke aloft downwind from the largest fires as compared to the past several days. Easterly transport winds will develop behind a backdoor cold front that will slowly advance toward the south and west late tonight into Wednesday with a reinforcing surge of east-northeast winds Wednesday evening. This change in the wind pattern will shift the focus for smoke impacts from the Hermits Peak Calf Canyon fire farther west and southwest. The relatively moist easterly winds eventually reaching the Continental Divide by late Wednesday. Significant smoke impacts should become much more localized going into Thursday and Friday and mainly focused in close proximity to the Black fire. * WHERE... Air quality may become unhealthy, at times, in close proximity to the Black fire including Winston, Chloride and neighboring communities along the Mimbres and Lower Rio Grande Valleys. Localized impacts are also expected in the vicinity of the Foster fire in the Bootheel. Elsewhere, deteriorating air quality may be encountered in the vicinity of Peasco, Pecos, Glorieta, Santa Fe, Eldorado and portions of the Espanola Valley and Galisteo Basin late tonight and Wednesday morning as residual smoke gets pushed west and southwestward. However, impacts here, if any, should be mostly moderate though residents should be prepared for changeable conditions around daybreak Wednesday. Light surface smoke may settle into portions of the Tularosa Basin and the Highway 380 corridor between San Antonio and Bingham tonight. There may also be increased haze or light smoke aloft for the Middle Rio Grande Valley and Estancia Basin next 24 hours. More details on impacted locations and latest air quality information can be found at https://fire.airnow.gov * WHEN... Remainder of this afternoon through at least 1pm MDT Wednesday, June 1.
